abstract.text: An interface that encodes a render pass into a command buffer, including all its draw calls and configuration.

inlineContent.text: protocol defines an interface that configures and encodes a render pass. Use a render pass to draw a scene, or a component within a scene, to its render
, the outputs of a render pass. You can use various approaches to render to those outputs, including techniques that apply the following:
To configure the render pass for your first drawing commands, start with a pipeline state by passing an
method. You create the pipeline states your render pass needs, typically ahead of time, by calling one or more
Avoid visual stutter by creating pipeline states at a noncritical time, such as during launch, because of the time it can take to make them.
Set any other applicable parts of the encoder’s configuration by calling the methods on the
page. For example, you may need to configure the pass’s viewport, its scissor rectangle, and the settings for depth and stencil tests.
Assign resources, such as buffers and textures, for the shaders that depend on them. For more information, see the shader-specific pages in the resource preparation section, such as
. If your shaders access resources through an argument buffer, ensure the pass makes those resources
by loading those resources resident in GPU memory. You do this by calling the methods on the
Encode drawing commands by calling the methods on the

page after you configure the state and resources the commands depend on. The encoder maintains its current state and applies them to all subsequent draw commands. For drawing commands that need different states or resources, reconfigure the render pass appropriately and then encode those draw commands. Repeat the process for each batch of drawing commands that depend on the same render pass configuration and resources.
When you finish encoding the render pass’s commands, finalize it into the command buffer by calling the encoder’s

abstract.text: Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
A container that stores a sequence of GPU commands that you encode into it.
Creates a render command encoder from a descriptor.
An encoder that writes GPU commands into a command buffer.
Declares that all command generation from the encoder is completed.
The mode that determines whether to perform culling and which type of primitive to cull.
The mode that determines how to deal with fragments outside of the near or far planes.
The main Metal interface to a GPU that apps use to draw graphics and run computations in parallel.
An option specifying that the app must prevent hazards when modifying this object’s contents.
The heap’s hazard tracking mode.
The index type for an index buffer that references vertices of geometric primitives.
An object that splits up a single render pass so that it can be simultaneously encoded from multiple threads.
Create an object that encodes commands that perform graphics rendering operations and may be assigned to a different thread.
The geometric primitive type for drawing commands.
An interface that encodes a render pass into a command buffer, including all its draw calls and configuration.
Encodes a command that runs an indirect range of commands from an indirect command buffer (ICB).
Encodes a command that runs a range of commands from an indirect command buffer (ICB).
Encodes a command that runs an indirect range of commands from an indirect command buffer (ICB).
Encodes a command that runs a range of commands from an indirect command buffer (ICB).
Creates a memory barrier that enforces the order of write and read operations for specific resources.
Creates a memory barrier that enforces the order of write and read operations for specific resource types.
Creates a memory barrier that enforces the order of write and read operations for specific resources.
Encodes a command that samples hardware counters during the render pass and stores the data into a counter sample buffer.
Configures the encoder with a render or tile pipeline state instance that applies to your subsequent draw commands.
Encodes a command that instructs the GPU to update a fence after one or more stages, which signals passes waiting on the fence.
Encodes a command that instructs the GPU to pause before starting one or more stages of the render pass until a pass updates a fence.
An interface that represents a graphics pipeline configuration for a render pass, which the pass applies to the draw commands you encode.
Specifies how to rasterize triangle and triangle strip primitives.
The mode that determines what, if anything, the GPU writes to the results buffer, after the GPU executes the render pass.
The vertex winding rule that determines a front-facing primitive.
Load individual resources and multiple resources within a heap into GPU memory so that they’re available to shaders through argument buffers.
Review unsupported symbols and their replacements.
Assign resources to fragment shaders, including buffers, textures, acceleration structures, sampler states, and function tables.
Optimize your app’s performance by grouping your resources into argument buffers.

abstract.text: Run draw commands that render to different outputs using the same vertex data multiple times.

abstract.text: Create pipeline states for render and compute passes, samplers, depth and stencil states, and indirect command buffers.
Set a render pass’s pipeline state, attachment actions, viewports, and so on, that affect subsequent drawing commands.
Render an image by drawing meshes, primitives, tessellation patches, and by dispatching tile shaders.
Retrieve a GPU’s counter data at a time the GPU supports.

abstract.text: Discover how Metal executes commands on a GPU.
Organize your resources into groups and influence when they become accessible to the GPU.

abstract.text: Assign resources to tile shaders, including buffers, textures, acceleration structures, sampler states, and function tables.
Optimize resource performance within an argument buffer.
